awd_titl_txt: CC*DNI Campus Design: Enhanced Data Delivery at Fort Hays State University
awd_abstract_narration:
Fort Hays State University is upgrading their campus network to support scientific data transfer needs of researchers in Physics, Informatics, Geosciences, and the Kansas Academy of Mathematics and Sciences. Activities include re-architecting the campus border with a design patterned after the science DMZ concept in campus research and education networking and establishing 10 Gbps connectivity for science data flows.

Scientific research collaborations across campus are enabled by these network upgrades. Physics faculty and student researchers run multiple simulations simultaneously to investigate the effect of lasers on human retinal tissue in collaboration with Kansas State University and the Air Force Research Laboratory, with the goal of producing safer lasers. Geoscience faculty and student researchers now access very large data files from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in investigating the causes of large, deadly tornados in Kansas and surrounding states.  In addition, they use mortality data provided by the U. S. Military Academy to correlate anomalous weather events and mortality. Additionally, investigators are analyzing archived data to establish the long-term weather trends in Kansas to document how global weather changes are affecting Kansas.  Informatics faculty and students have created a big data (Hadoop) platform that is being used to mine vast quantities of unstructured data located across the Internet to assist Geoscience and Informatics research. Kansas Academy of Math and Science (an early college entrance STEM program) students are now using LandSat imagery data for their research projects.  Informatics researchers use the expanded reach and improved network monitoring tools to test more advanced network protocols. The results of these experiments will be shared in publications, conferences, FHSU workshops, and archived in a data repository.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF CC*DNI Campus Design: Enhanced Data Delivery at Fort Hays State University grant facilitated the creation of reliable and secure data pathways for research and teaching. Because this grant funded cyberinfrastructure, FHSU upgraded the border router, upgraded the core router to handle 10 gb traffic from researchers in selected buildings, installed a network monitoring system (PerfSONAR), added storage dedicated to research needs, and created a data transfer server to move data securely and reliably over the Internet. Research scientists now have a “demilitarized zone” to use for their purposes that does not harm the normal University Internet traffic. With the help of networking staff FHSU researchers can now connect directly to high performance servers elsewhere or to the high -performance data server that they now use to share data with others.   

As a result of this upgrade and network redesign, FHSU researchers are now able to engage in enhanced research activities such as:

  • Physics researchers now routinely run simulations remotely at the Kansas State University high performance computing cluster.These simulations help improve ANSI safety standards in the use of lasers (related to human retinas) in collaboration with researchers at the United States Air Force Research Laboratory in San Antonio.
  • A graduate student is now using a PC with multiple video processors to produce ultra high-speed photography in collaboration with a researcher in San Antonio.
  • A geoscience researcher shares weather-related mortality data with a colleague at West Point, and he analyzes large quantities of data related to tornadic activity across the United States.
  • A biology researcher is now able to share large datasets created by drones using high definition cameras and Lidar sensors with a colleague at Kansas State University Polytechnic in Salina, Kansas.
  • The Director of the New Media Institute can now use high definition video streaming and high-speed data delivery to colleagues at the University of Illinois (Chicago) and at the University of Hawaii. 
  • The Kansas Academy of Mathematics and Science (KAMS), a residential early-college entrance STEM program for high school students can now use the data transfer server to send and receive sensor data from high weather balloons as well as to access atmospheric data from federal weather sites.
  • Informatics faculty can now use the PerfSONAR server for research purposes, and they will be able to use PerfSONAR on a new Netlab simulator in the future.  

Some examples of results include:

  • The laser simulations have helped to refine safety standards so that lasers can be used without damaging human retinas. Dr. C. D. Clark, a member of the ANSI committee, is helping to redefine the standards.
  • Dr. C. D. Clark also works with a graduate student who has programmed video processors to do ultra high-speed photography. This will enable researchers to study laser travel through various media and other high-speed tasks. 
  • Dr. Grady Dixon has published articles assessing tornadic damage based on new ways of analyzing the national data. He has also published articles on how heat affects human mortality.
  • KAMS student researchers have gotten real world experience in collecting atmospheric data using high-altitude balloons.
  • Biology students have gained skills is controlling drones and in using sophisticated software to stitch together the drone data into 3-D models of surveyed areas.
  • Dr. Gordon Carlson’s students in the Institute of New Media Studies use software to create 3-D models. Dr. Carlson conducts many workshops for the public that feature using high definition video and 3-D modelling.  
  • The PerfSONAR platform will be used by Jason Zeller (Informatics Professor) in his doctoral research with colleagues at the University of South Florida and the University of South Carolina to create a virtual lab to teach PerfSONAR principles (NSF Grants #1822567 and #1829698).
  • The Networking Staff learned valuable lessons while setting up the Science DMZ, lessons that they will share with colleagues across the state. 

There are also many examples of outreach, including:

  • The Science and Mathematics Education Institute hosted a workshop for high school STEM instructors and counsellors entitled “Career Options in STEM Data Literacy Workshop at FHSU” that featured many of the NSF-assisted instructors. The workshop featured ways of using large datasets and the various career paths that are becoming available to those using big data.
  • Dr. Bill Stark helped organize and speak at the Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) Workshop, “Getting Started with UAS in Western Kansas,” held on the FHSU campus. It featured industry experts, FAA personnel, Kansas KDOT representatives, and university users of the UAS technology. The event had 80 attendees.
  • The monthly Science Café hosted by the FHSU Science and Math Education Institute attracts faculty, students, and others from the community. Most of the researchers affected by the grant have shared their work there. 

The researchers and instructors have made good use of the new research environment made possible by this grant.
